epidemiology: Most common type of anemia worldwide. Affects >25% of global population, especially children and women of reproductive age.
treatment_protocol: Identify cause → Start iron therapy → Monitor Hb and ferritin → Reassess in 3 months

epidemiology: Common in the elderly, vegetarians, and patients with malabsorption. Prevalence increases with age.

definitive: Parenteral or high-dose oral B12 replacement

treatment_protocol: Confirm diagnosis → Replace B12 → Monitor response → Address underlying cause

epidemiology: Common in alcoholics, pregnant women, and patients with malabsorption. Often coexists with B12 deficiency.
treatment_protocol: Confirm deficiency → Oral folate → Monitor Hb and MCV → Prevent recurrence

epidemiology: Common among individuals of African, Mediterranean, Middle Eastern, and Indian ancestry. Inherited autosomal recessive hemoglobinopathy.
treatment_protocol: Prevent crises → Use hydroxyurea → Transfusions for severe complications → Consider transplant

epidemiology: Rare disorder, incidence 2–6 per million annually. Can be acquired (autoimmune, drug-related) or inherited.

emergency_markers: Profound pancytopenia with sepsis or bleeding

treatment_protocol: Confirm diagnosis → Immunotherapy if no donor → Transplant if eligible

epidemiology: Uncommon; incidence of ~1–3 per 100,000 per year. More frequent in females. Warm type more common than cold.
treatment_protocol: Confirm with Coombs → Start steroids → Consider rituximab/splenectomy if refractory

epidemiology: Common in Mediterranean, Middle Eastern, and Southeast Asian populations. Autosomal recessive inheritance.

emergency_markers: Heart failure from anemia or iron overload

treatment_protocol: Confirm diagnosis → Transfusion schedule → Chelation → Consider transplant

epidemiology: Most common inherited hemolytic anemia in people of Northern European descent. Autosomal dominant in most cases.
treatment_protocol: Supportive care → Splenectomy if severe → Monitor for complications

epidemiology: Chronic myeloproliferative neoplasm. Median age at diagnosis ~60 years. Associated with JAK2 mutation.
treatment_protocol: Diagnose with CBC + JAK2 → Phlebotomy → Cytoreduction if high-risk

epidemiology: Myeloproliferative neoplasm with elevated platelet count. Affects women more than men. Median age at diagnosis ~60 years.
treatment_protocol: Assess risk → Aspirin → Cytoreduction in high-risk → Regular monitoring

epidemiology: Accounts for 15–20% of adult leukemias. Median age ~55. Strongly associated with BCR-ABL fusion gene (Philadelphia chromosome).
treatment_protocol: Confirm BCR-ABL → Start TKI → Monitor response → Transplant if resistant

epidemiology: Most common cancer in children, especially between ages 2–5. Higher incidence in males.
treatment_protocol: Induction → Consolidation → Maintenance → Monitor for relapse

epidemiology: Common in adults >60 years. Represents ~80% of adult acute leukemias.
treatment_protocol: Diagnose → Induction → Consolidation → Consider transplant in eligible patients

epidemiology: Second most common hematologic malignancy in adults. Incidence increases with age. More common in African descent.
treatment_protocol: Diagnose → Induction → Transplant in eligible → Maintenance therapy

epidemiology: Common in elderly (median age 70). Often secondary to chemotherapy/radiation or idiopathic.

emergency_markers: Profound cytopenias with infection or bleeding

treatment_protocol: Risk stratification → Supportive care → Disease-modifying agents → Transplant if eligible

epidemiology: Most common leukemia in adults in Western countries. More common in men and the elderly.
treatment_protocol: Monitor → Start treatment if symptomatic → Use targeted agents → Evaluate for transplant

epidemiology: Rare but life-threatening. Common in Asia. Can be idiopathic or secondary to drugs, viruses, or autoimmune disease.
treatment_protocol: Confirm pancytopenia → Identify cause → Start IST or consider SCT

epidemiology: X-linked recessive disorder. Affects 1 in 5,000 male births globally. Deficiency of factor VIII.

emergency_markers: Head trauma with suspected intracranial bleed

treatment_protocol: Diagnosis → Replace factor → Prevent bleeds → Monitor inhibitors

epidemiology: X-linked recessive disorder. Deficiency of factor IX. Also known as Christmas disease.
treatment_protocol: Confirm with labs → Factor IX replacement → Preventive care

epidemiology: Autoimmune platelet destruction. Common in children post-viral and in adults (chronic form).
treatment_protocol: Diagnosis → Start steroids/IVIG → Monitor → Consider splenectomy

epidemiology: Most common inherited bleeding disorder. Affects 1% of the population. Usually autosomal dominant.
treatment_protocol: Identify type → Desmopressin trial → Factor replacement if severe

epidemiology: Autosomal recessive disorder common in Mediterranean, Middle East, and parts of Asia. Presents in early childhood.
treatment_protocol: Early diagnosis → Transfusions → Chelation → Evaluate for transplant

epidemiology: Milder form of thalassemia. Common carrier state in malaria-endemic regions.
treatment_protocol: Identify via screening → Counsel → Monitor as needed

epidemiology: Rare acquired clonal hematopoietic stem cell disorder. Affects young adults.
treatment_protocol: Confirm diagnosis → Start complement inhibition → Consider transplant

epidemiology: Chronic myeloproliferative disorder. Common in adults >50 years. JAK2 mutation in >95%.
treatment_protocol: Diagnose → Reduce risk of thrombosis → Monitor and manage progression

epidemiology: Myeloproliferative disorder marked by elevated platelet count. Median age 60, more common in females.
treatment_protocol: Risk stratification → Antiplatelet or cytoreductive therapy → Regular monitoring

epidemiology: Clonal hematopoietic stem cell disorders, primarily in elderly. Risk of progression to AML.
treatment_protocol: Stratify risk → Supportive care or chemotherapy → SCT for high-risk

epidemiology: Myeloproliferative neoplasm. Philadelphia chromosome (t(9;22)) leads to BCR-ABL fusion. Common in adults 40-60 years.
treatment_protocol: Confirm BCR-ABL → Start TKI → Monitor molecular response

epidemiology: Malignancy of myeloid precursors. Common in older adults. Can be secondary to MDS or therapy-related.
treatment_protocol: Confirm AML → Induction chemo → Consolidation or transplant

epidemiology: Common childhood leukemia. Also seen in adults. Risk increases in Down syndrome.
treatment_protocol: Diagnose → Induction → Consolidation → Maintenance

epidemiology: Most common adult leukemia in Western countries. Median age at diagnosis ~70 years.
treatment_protocol: Monitor early stages → Treat if symptomatic → Regular follow-up

epidemiology: Rare chronic B-cell leukemia. Predominantly affects middle-aged to older men.
treatment_protocol: Confirm with smear + TRAP → Cladribine therapy → Monitor cytopenias

epidemiology: X-linked recessive bleeding disorder due to factor VIII deficiency. Primarily affects males.
treatment_protocol: Replace factor VIII → Monitor bleeding control → Screen for inhibitors

epidemiology: X-linked recessive disorder due to factor IX deficiency. Clinically similar to Hemophilia A.
treatment_protocol: Confirm diagnosis → Factor IX infusion → Bleed monitoring

epidemiology: Autoimmune platelet destruction. More common in children (acute) and adult females (chronic).
treatment_protocol: Assess severity → Start steroids or IVIG → Escalate if refractory

epidemiology: Most common inherited bleeding disorder. Affects both sexes. Autosomal dominant.
treatment_protocol: Diagnose → DDAVP trial → Factor concentrates if needed

epidemiology: Rare, life-threatening thrombotic microangiopathy. More common in adults, especially women.
treatment_protocol: Urgent plasma exchange → Monitor platelets → Immunosuppression

epidemiology: Most common in children. Often follows E. coli O157:H7 infection. Triad: hemolysis, renal failure, thrombocytopenia.
treatment_protocol: Supportive care → Manage renal function → Monitor labs

epidemiology: Chronic myeloproliferative disorder with elevated platelet count. Affects adults, often asymptomatic.
treatment_protocol: Risk stratification → Aspirin ± cytoreduction → Monitor counts

epidemiology: Myeloproliferative neoplasm with increased red cell mass. JAK2 mutation in >95% cases. Median age ~60 years.
treatment_protocol: Phlebotomy to HCT <45% → Cytoreduction if high risk

epidemiology: Chronic myeloproliferative disorder with bone marrow fibrosis. Often secondary to PV or ET. Affects older adults.
treatment_protocol: Risk stratification → JAK inhibitor → Consider SCT in high-risk

epidemiology: Rare bone marrow failure syndrome. Can be acquired (autoimmune, drugs, viruses) or inherited. Affects all age groups.
treatment_protocol: Diagnose → IST or SCT → Monitor recovery

epidemiology: Most common leukemia in adults in the Western world. Median age ~70 years.
treatment_protocol: Assess stage → Monitor or treat → Response evaluation

epidemiology: Myeloproliferative neoplasm associated with BCR-ABL fusion gene. Median age ~50 years.
treatment_protocol: Confirm BCR-ABL → Start TKI → Monitor response (PCR)

epidemiology: Plasma cell malignancy affecting older adults (~70 years). More common in Black population.
treatment_protocol: Confirm diagnosis → Induction therapy → SCT if eligible → Maintenance

epidemiology: Indolent B-cell lymphoma producing IgM. Affects elderly. Median age ~70 years.
treatment_protocol: Assess symptoms → Start therapy if symptomatic → Monitor IgM

epidemiology: Rare acquired clonal hematopoietic stem cell disorder. Median age ~30-40 years.
treatment_protocol: Flow cytometry → Start complement inhibitor → Monitor labs

epidemiology: Autosomal dominant hemolytic anemia due to membrane protein defect (e.g., ankyrin, spectrin). Common in Northern Europeans.
treatment_protocol: Diagnose with labs → Manage with folate ± splenectomy

epidemiology: X-linked recessive. Common in African, Mediterranean, and Asian populations. Hemolysis triggered by stress, drugs, or infection.
treatment_protocol: Avoid triggers → Supportive care → Transfuse if necessary

epidemiology: Rare cause of acquired hemolysis. Can be idiopathic or secondary to lupus, CLL, etc.
treatment_protocol: Confirm with Coombs → Start steroids → Escalate if refractory

epidemiology: X-linked recessive disorder of factor VIII. Affects males. ~1 in 5,000 male births.
treatment_protocol: Replace factor VIII → Prophylaxis → Manage complications

epidemiology: X-linked recessive disorder of factor IX. Less common than Hemophilia A. Affects ~1 in 25,000 male births.
treatment_protocol: Diagnose → Factor IX replacement → Prophylaxis

epidemiology: Autoimmune platelet destruction. Bimodal peak in children and adults. Female > Male in adults.
treatment_protocol: Start steroids or IVIG → Monitor → Splenectomy if chronic

epidemiology: Rare, life-threatening thrombotic microangiopathy. Deficiency of ADAMTS13 enzyme. More common in women.
treatment_protocol: Suspect → Urgent plasma exchange → Confirm with ADAMTS13

epidemiology: Myeloproliferative neoplasm. Often JAK2, CALR, or MPL mutation positive. Median age 60 years.
treatment_protocol: Assess risk → Aspirin ± cytoreduction → Monitor

epidemiology: Chronic myeloproliferative neoplasm due to JAK2 mutation. Incidence ~2/100,000 per year. Median age ~60 years.
treatment_protocol: Diagnose → Risk stratify → Start phlebotomy ± cytoreduction

epidemiology: Group of clonal hematopoietic disorders common in elderly; incidence increases with age (>65). Risk of transformation to AML.
treatment_protocol: Risk stratify → Supportive care → Consider azacitidine or transplant

epidemiology: Rare, life-threatening pancytopenia due to bone marrow failure. Can be idiopathic or due to drugs, toxins, infections.

emergency_markers: Profound pancytopenia with sepsis or bleeding

treatment_protocol: Identify cause → Treat infections → Immunosuppression or transplant

epidemiology: Myeloproliferative neoplasm with BCR-ABL fusion (Philadelphia chromosome). Median age ~55 years.
treatment_protocol: Confirm BCR-ABL → Start TKI → Monitor response

epidemiology: Most common adult leukemia in Western countries. Usually >60 years old. Often incidental finding.
treatment_protocol: Staging → Monitor or treat depending on symptoms/genetics

epidemiology: Rare indolent B-cell leukemia. Affects middle-aged males. ~2% of all leukemias.
treatment_protocol: Confirm diagnosis → Start purine analog → Monitor response

epidemiology: Subtype of AML with t(15;17) translocation. Accounts for 10–15% of AML cases. Often presents with coagulopathy.
treatment_protocol: Suspect APL → Initiate ATRA immediately → Confirm PML-RARA → Continue therapy ± chemo

epidemiology: Rare acquired clonal stem cell disorder. Incidence ~1–2 per million/year. Common in young adults.
treatment_protocol: Confirm diagnosis → Start complement inhibitor → Monitor labs

epidemiology: Rare autoimmune hemolytic anemia. Often idiopathic or post-infectious (Mycoplasma, EBV). More common in elderly.
treatment_protocol: Avoid cold → Treat underlying cause → Immunotherapy

epidemiology: Autosomal recessive iron overload disorder (HFE gene mutation). Most common in Caucasians of Northern European descent.

supportive: Avoid iron supplements and vitamin C

treatment_protocol: Confirm overload → Start phlebotomy → Monitor ferritin

epidemiology: Defective heme synthesis → iron trapping in mitochondria. Congenital or acquired (alcohol, drugs, lead). Rare.
treatment_protocol: Identify cause → Replace B6 → Monitor response

epidemiology: X-linked recessive bleeding disorder due to factor VIII deficiency. Affects ~1 in 5,000 male births.
treatment_protocol: Diagnose → Factor replacement → Prevent and treat bleeds

epidemiology: X-linked recessive disorder due to factor IX deficiency. ~1 in 25,000 male births. Clinically similar to Hemophilia A.
treatment_protocol: Confirm diagnosis → Replace factor IX → Monitor for inhibitors

epidemiology: Most common inherited bleeding disorder. Affects ~1% of population. Often mild and undiagnosed.

emergency_markers: Major surgery or trauma in vWD patients

treatment_protocol: Classify type → Desmopressin trial → Factor/vWF replacement as needed

epidemiology: Autoimmune platelet destruction. Acute form more common in children post-infection. Chronic form more common in adults.
treatment_protocol: Initial steroids → IVIG if bleeding → Chronic Rx if persistent

epidemiology: Rare, life-threatening microangiopathy due to ADAMTS13 deficiency. Affects ~4–5 per million/year. Mostly adults.
treatment_protocol: Suspect → Start plasma exchange → Confirm diagnosis → Add immunosuppression
